{"step_by_step_thinking": "Oral hairy leukoplakia is characterized by white, hairy patches on the side of the tongue, not spongy, folded thick mucosa. Aspirin burn would cause a painful, white or gray lesion, not a spongy, folded thick mucosa. Pseudomembranous Candidiasis is characterized by creamy white, curd-like patches on the tongue and other areas inside the mouth, not spongy, folded thick mucosa. White spongy nevus, however, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by white, spongy, folded thick mucosa in the oral cavity.", "answer_choice": "C. White spongy nevus"}
